nodes.name: Management and Organizational Behavior
nodes.name_jp: マネジメントと組織行動
nodes.description: The overarching framework that encompasses all organizational elements

nodes.name: Nature of Work
nodes.description: Explores what constitutes work and its role in organizational contexts

nodes.name: Nature of Management
nodes.description: Defines management functions and responsibilities

nodes.name: Changing Workplace
nodes.description: Addresses contemporary workplace transformations

nodes.name: OB and Management Model
nodes.name_jp: OB・マネジメントモデル
nodes.description: The integrated framework combining organizational behavior with management functions

nodes.name: Technological Advancement
nodes.description: Digital transformation and automation in workplace

nodes.name: Globalization
nodes.description: International expansion and cross-border operations

nodes.name: Workforce Diversity
nodes.description: Variety in employee demographics and backgrounds

nodes.name: Remote Work
nodes.description: Work conducted outside traditional office locations

nodes.name: Work-Life Balance
nodes.name_jp: ワークライフバランス
nodes.description: Integration of work and personal life priorities

nodes.name: Planning
nodes.description: Setting organizational goals and strategies

nodes.name: Organizing
nodes.description: Structuring resources and responsibilities

nodes.name: Leading
nodes.description: Influencing and motivating people

nodes.name: Controlling
nodes.description: Monitoring and adjusting performance

nodes.name: Decision-Making
nodes.description: Making choices about organizational direction

nodes.name: Resource Allocation
nodes.description: Distributing assets effectively

nodes.name: Personality
nodes.description: Individual traits affecting work behavior

nodes.name: Motivation
nodes.description: Drive to perform and achieve goals

nodes.name: Perception
nodes.description: How individuals interpret organizational information

nodes.name: Attitudes
nodes.description: Predispositions toward work and organization

nodes.name: Skills and Abilities
nodes.description: Competencies for task performance

nodes.name: Personal Values
nodes.description: Fundamental beliefs guiding behavior

nodes.name: Team Dynamics
nodes.description: Interaction patterns within groups

nodes.name: Communication
nodes.description: Information exchange and coordination

nodes.name: Conflict
nodes.description: Disagreements and their resolution

nodes.name: Group Leadership
nodes.name_jp: グループリーダーシップ
nodes.description: Influence within group settings

nodes.name: Group Cohesion
nodes.description: Unity and solidarity of group members

nodes.name: Organizational Structure
nodes.description: Formal arrangement of roles and relationships

nodes.name: Organizational Culture
nodes.description: Shared values, beliefs, and norms

nodes.name: Strategy
nodes.description: Long-term organizational direction

nodes.name: Organizational Environment
nodes.description: External factors affecting the organization

nodes.name: Organizational Design
nodes.description: Intentional structuring for effectiveness

nodes.name: Inputs
nodes.description: Individual and organizational characteristics that enter the system

nodes.name: Processes
nodes.description: Behaviors, interactions, and decision-making activities

nodes.name: Outputs
nodes.description: Performance, satisfaction, and organizational success results

nodes.name: Individual Performance
nodes.description: Task completion and quality metrics

nodes.name: Group Effectiveness
nodes.description: Team goal achievement and collaboration success

nodes.name: Organizational Success
nodes.description: Overall organizational objectives and strategic goals

nodes.name: Employee Satisfaction
nodes.description: Worker contentment and engagement levels

nodes.name: Individual and Cultural Differences
nodes.description: Factors affecting employee performance based on individual and cultural backgrounds

nodes.name: Individual and Cultural Factors in Employee Performance
nodes.name_cn: 员工绩效中的个人和文化因素
nodes.name_jp: 従業員パフォーマンスにおける個人と文化要因
nodes.description: How individual characteristics and cultural background influence work performance

nodes.name: Employee Abilities and Skills
nodes.name_jp: 従業員の能力とスキル
nodes.description: Competencies and capabilities that employees bring to their roles

nodes.name: Personality: An Introduction
nodes.description: Overview of personality traits and their role in organizations

nodes.name: Personality and Work Behavior
nodes.description: How personality traits influence workplace behavior and performance

nodes.name: Personality and Organization: A Basic Conflict?
nodes.name_jp: 性格と組織：基本的な葛藤？
nodes.description: Tensions between individual personality and organizational requirements

nodes.name: Personal Values and Ethics
nodes.description: Fundamental beliefs and ethical principles guiding individual behavior

nodes.name: Cultural Differences
nodes.description: How cultural backgrounds influence organizational behavior and performance

nodes.name: Cognitive Ability
nodes.description: Mental capacity for learning, reasoning, and problem-solving

nodes.name: Technical Skills
nodes.description: Job-specific technical competencies and expertise

nodes.name: Interpersonal Skills
nodes.description: Ability to work effectively with others

nodes.name: Big Five Personality Traits
nodes.name_jp: ビッグファイブ性格特性
nodes.description: Openness, Conscientiousness, Extraversion, Agreeableness, Neuroticism

nodes.name: Emotional Intelligence
nodes.description: Ability to recognize and manage emotions in self and others

nodes.name: Personal Ethics
nodes.description: Individual moral principles and ethical standards

nodes.name: Work Values
nodes.description: What individuals value in their work environment and career

nodes.name: Hofstede Cultural Dimensions
nodes.name_jp: ホフステッド文化的次元
nodes.description: Framework for understanding cultural differences across societies

nodes.name: Power Distance
nodes.description: Extent to which less powerful members accept unequal power distribution

nodes.name: Uncertainty Avoidance
nodes.description: Degree to which cultures avoid or embrace uncertainty

nodes.name: Individualism vs Collectivism
nodes.name_cn: 个人主义 vs 集体主义
nodes.name_jp: 個人主義 vs 集団主義
nodes.description: Cultural preference for individual or group interests

nodes.name: Masculinity vs Femininity
nodes.name_cn: 男性气质 vs 女性气质
nodes.name_jp: 男性性 vs 女性性
nodes.description: Cultural emphasis on achievement versus relationship orientation

nodes.name: Time Orientation
nodes.description: Cultural focus on past, present, or future

nodes.name: Demographic Diversity
nodes.description: Differences in age, gender, race, ethnicity, and other demographics

nodes.name: Cognitive Diversity
nodes.description: Differences in thinking styles, problem-solving approaches, and perspectives

nodes.name: Value Diversity
nodes.description: Differences in personal values and ethical frameworks

nodes.name: Person-Job Fit
nodes.description: Alignment between individual characteristics and job requirements

nodes.name: Person-Organization Fit
nodes.description: Alignment between individual values and organizational culture

nodes.name: Cultural Adaptation
nodes.description: Ability to adjust to different cultural environments

nodes.name: Perception and Job Attitudes
nodes.description: How employees perceive their work environment and develop attitudes toward their jobs

nodes.name: Perception: An Introduction
nodes.description: Overview of perception processes and their role in organizational behavior

nodes.name: The Perception Process
nodes.description: How individuals select, organize, and interpret sensory information

nodes.name: Social Perception
nodes.description: How people perceive and evaluate other people

nodes.name: Job Attitudes
nodes.description: Employees' feelings and beliefs about their work and organization

nodes.name: Job Satisfaction
nodes.description: Degree to which employees are satisfied with their jobs

nodes.name: Organizational Commitment
nodes.description: Employee attachment and loyalty to the organization

nodes.name: Selective Attention
nodes.description: Process of focusing on certain stimuli while ignoring others

nodes.name: Organization and Schema
nodes.description: Mental frameworks for organizing and interpreting information

nodes.name: Interpretation
nodes.description: Process of assigning meaning to perceived information

nodes.name: Perceptual Bias
nodes.description: Systematic errors in perception and judgment

nodes.name: Attribution Theory
nodes.description: How people explain the causes of behavior

nodes.name: First Impression
nodes.description: Initial judgments formed about people

nodes.name: Stereotyping
nodes.description: Assigning characteristics to people based on group membership

nodes.name: Job Involvement
nodes.description: Degree to which employees identify with and care about their work

nodes.name: Affective Commitment
nodes.name_jp: 情動的コミットメント
nodes.description: Emotional attachment to the organization

nodes.name: Continuance Commitment
nodes.name_jp: 継続的コミットメント
nodes.description: Commitment based on costs of leaving the organization

nodes.name: Normative Commitment
nodes.name_jp: 規範的コミットメント
nodes.description: Commitment based on sense of obligation to the organization

nodes.name: Job Stress
nodes.description: Psychological and physiological strain from work demands

nodes.name: Burnout
nodes.description: Emotional exhaustion and reduced effectiveness from prolonged stress

nodes.name: Cognitive Complexity
nodes.description: Capacity to acquire and organize information in sophisticated ways

nodes.name: Self-Esteem
nodes.description: Individual's belief about their own worth and capabilities

nodes.name: Self-Efficacy
nodes.description: Belief in one's ability to succeed in specific situations

nodes.name: Locus of Control
nodes.description: Tendency to attribute events to internal or external causes

nodes.name: Internal Locus of Control
nodes.description: Belief that events are controlled by one's own actions

nodes.name: External Locus of Control
nodes.description: Belief that events are controlled by external forces

nodes.name: Introversion-Extroversion
nodes.description: Dimension of personality reflecting social orientation

nodes.name: Dogmatism
nodes.description: Cognitive style characterized by closed-mindedness

nodes.name: Authoritarianism
nodes.description: Orientation toward authority and hierarchical relationships

nodes.name: Work Performance
nodes.description: Quality and quantity of work output

nodes.name: Organizational Citizenship Behavior
nodes.description: Voluntary behaviors that benefit the organization

nodes.name: Turnover Intention
nodes.description: Employee's intention to leave the organization

nodes.name: Absenteeism
nodes.description: Frequency of employee absence from work

nodes.name: Learning and Reinforcement
nodes.description: How employees acquire knowledge and skills through various learning processes

nodes.name: Learning: An Introduction
nodes.description: Overview of learning processes and their importance in organizations

nodes.name: Basic Models of Learning
nodes.description: Classical conditioning, operant conditioning, social learning, and cognitive learning

nodes.name: Reinforcement Theory
nodes.description: How reinforcement shapes and maintains behavior in organizations

nodes.name: Behavior Modification
nodes.description: Systematic application of reinforcement principles to change behavior

nodes.name: Classical Conditioning
nodes.description: Learning through association of neutral stimulus with unconditioned stimulus

nodes.name: Operant Conditioning
nodes.description: Learning through consequences of behavior (rewards and punishments)

nodes.name: Social Learning Theory
nodes.description: Learning through observation and imitation of role models

nodes.name: Cognitive Learning
nodes.description: Learning through mental processes and problem-solving

nodes.name: Positive Reinforcement
nodes.description: Adding a desirable consequence to increase behavior frequency

nodes.name: Negative Reinforcement
nodes.description: Removing an undesirable consequence to increase behavior frequency

nodes.name: Punishment
nodes.description: Adding an undesirable consequence to decrease behavior frequency

nodes.name: Extinction
nodes.description: Removing reinforcement to decrease behavior frequency

nodes.name: Law of Effect
nodes.description: Behaviors followed by positive consequences are more likely to be repeated

nodes.name: Vicarious Learning
nodes.description: Learning through observation of others and their consequences

nodes.name: Attention
nodes.description: Focusing on relevant information during learning

nodes.name: Retention
nodes.description: Storing learned information in memory

nodes.name: Reproduction
nodes.description: Converting learned information into observable behavior

nodes.name: Incentives
nodes.description: Rewards or motivations that influence learning processes

nodes.name: Motivation to Learn
nodes.description: Individual's desire and willingness to acquire new knowledge

nodes.name: Prior Knowledge
nodes.description: Existing knowledge that facilitates learning of new material

nodes.name: Feedback
nodes.description: Information about performance that enhances learning

nodes.name: Whole vs Part Learning
nodes.name_cn: 整体 vs 部分学习
nodes.name_jp: 全体 vs 部分学習
nodes.description: Learning integrated tasks as whole or learning separate parts

nodes.name: Massed vs Distributed Practice
nodes.name_cn: 集中 vs 分散练习
nodes.name_jp: 集中 vs 分散練習
nodes.description: Concentrated practice versus spaced practice over time

nodes.name: Behavioral Criteria
nodes.description: Clear specification of acceptable behavior and performance

nodes.name: Performance Audit
nodes.description: Assessment of current performance against desired criteria

nodes.name: Behavioral Goals
nodes.description: Specific, measurable, and achievable behavior targets

nodes.name: Shaping
nodes.description: Reinforcing successive approximations to desired behavior

nodes.name: Skill Acquisition
nodes.description: Development of new competencies and capabilities

nodes.name: Behavior Change
nodes.description: Modification of employee behavior through reinforcement

nodes.name: Performance Improvement
nodes.description: Enhanced work output and effectiveness

nodes.name: Diversity in Organizations
nodes.description: Understanding and managing workforce diversity for organizational effectiveness

nodes.name: Introduction to Workplace Diversity
nodes.description: Overview of diversity dimensions and their importance in organizations

nodes.name: Impact of Diversity
nodes.description: How diversity affects company performance and workforce dynamics

nodes.name: Diversity Challenges
nodes.description: Managing conflicts and challenges arising from workforce diversity

nodes.name: Managing Diversity
nodes.description: Strategies and practices for effectively managing diverse workforces

nodes.name: Gender Diversity
nodes.description: Differences in gender representation and gender-based experiences

nodes.name: Race and Ethnicity
nodes.description: Racial and ethnic diversity in the workforce

nodes.name: Age Diversity
nodes.description: Generational differences and age-related workforce dynamics

nodes.name: Disability Diversity
nodes.description: Inclusion of employees with physical and mental disabilities

nodes.name: Sexual Orientation
nodes.description: LGBTQ+ diversity and inclusion in workplace

nodes.name: Gender Identity
nodes.description: Diversity in gender identity and expression

nodes.name: National Origin
nodes.description: Diversity based on country of origin and cultural background

nodes.name: Religion
nodes.description: Religious beliefs and practices diversity

nodes.name: Women Employees
nodes.description: Female workforce members and gender-related workplace experiences

nodes.name: Black Employees
nodes.description: African American and Black workforce members

nodes.name: Asian and Asian American Employees
nodes.description: Asian and Asian American workforce members

nodes.name: Multiracial Employees
nodes.description: Employees identifying with multiple racial backgrounds

nodes.name: Older Workers
nodes.description: Employees age 40 and above

nodes.name: Younger Workers
nodes.description: Younger generation employees and early career professionals

nodes.name: LGBTQ+ Employees
nodes.description: Lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and queer employees

nodes.name: Employees with Disabilities
nodes.description: Employees with physical or mental disabilities

nodes.name: Workplace Discrimination
nodes.description: Unfair treatment based on protected characteristics

nodes.name: Harassment
nodes.description: Unwelcome conduct based on protected characteristics

nodes.name: Sexual Harassment
nodes.name_jp: セクシュアルハラスメント
nodes.description: Harassment based on sex including unwanted advances

nodes.name: Age Discrimination
nodes.description: Unfair treatment based on age, especially for employees 40+

nodes.name: Disability Discrimination
nodes.description: Unfair treatment based on disability status

nodes.name: Reverse Discrimination
nodes.description: Perceived discrimination against dominant groups

nodes.name: Pay Inequity
nodes.description: Unequal compensation for equal work

nodes.name: Equal Employment Opportunity Commission
nodes.description: Federal agency enforcing employment discrimination laws

nodes.name: Civil Rights Act of 1964
nodes.description: Federal law prohibiting discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex, or national origin

nodes.name: Equal Pay Act of 1963
nodes.description: Law mandating equal pay for equal work regardless of gender

nodes.name: Age Discrimination in Employment Act
nodes.description: Federal law prohibiting age discrimination for employees 40 and above

nodes.name: Americans with Disabilities Act
nodes.description: Federal law prohibiting discrimination against individuals with disabilities

nodes.name: Discrimination and Fairness Perspective
nodes.description: Focus on eliminating discrimination and ensuring fair treatment

nodes.name: Access and Legitimacy Perspective
nodes.name_jp: アクセスと正当性の視点
nodes.description: Leveraging diversity to access diverse markets and customer bases

nodes.name: Integration and Learning Perspective
nodes.description: Using diversity to enhance organizational learning and innovation

nodes.name: Structured Interview Process
nodes.description: Standardized interview procedures to reduce bias in hiring

nodes.name: Blind Recruiting
nodes.description: Removing identifying information to reduce bias in selection

nodes.name: Diversity Training Programs
nodes.name_jp: 多様性トレーニングプログラム
nodes.description: Educational programs to increase awareness and reduce discrimination

nodes.name: Diversified Mentoring Relationships
nodes.name_jp: 多様化されたメンタリング関係
nodes.description: Cross-cultural and cross-status mentoring for mutual learning

nodes.name: Inclusion Programs
nodes.name_jp: インクルージョンプログラム
nodes.description: Organizational initiatives to ensure all employees feel valued

nodes.name: Competitive Advantage
nodes.description: Enhanced market position through diverse perspectives and experiences

nodes.name: Innovation
nodes.description: Enhanced creativity and problem-solving from diverse teams

nodes.name: Financial Performance
nodes.description: Improved profitability and business results

nodes.name: Employee Engagement
nodes.name_jp: 従業員エンゲージメント
nodes.description: Increased commitment and satisfaction among diverse employees

nodes.name: Organizational Reputation
nodes.description: Enhanced brand image and stakeholder trust

nodes.name: Chapter 19: Entrepreneurship
nodes.description: 組織行動学における起業家精神の概念、種類、成功要因、およびビジネスモデルキャンバスについて。

nodes.name: Chapter 06: Perception and Managerial Decision Making
nodes.name_jp: 第06章：知覚と管理的意思決定
nodes.description: This chapter explores the process of perception, how it influences managerial decision-making, the types of decisions, common decision-making biases, and techniques for improving decision quality.

nodes.name: Perception
nodes.description: A process by which individuals organize and interpret their sensory impressions in order to give meaning to their environment.

nodes.name: Managerial Decision Making
nodes.description: The process of choosing a course of action for dealing with a problem or opportunity.

nodes.name: Programmed Decision
nodes.description: A decision that is repetitive and routine, for which a specific procedure has been developed.

nodes.name: Non-programmed Decision
nodes.description: A decision that is unique and non-routine, requiring a custom-made solution.

nodes.name: Heuristics
nodes.description: Mental shortcuts or rules of thumb that people use to make judgments quickly and efficiently.

nodes.name: Bounded Rationality
nodes.description: The idea that decision makers are limited by their cognitive abilities, time, and information, leading to "satisficing" rather than optimizing.

nodes.name: The Perceptual Process
nodes.description: The sequence of steps from environmental stimuli to action: selection, organization, and interpretation.

nodes.name: Ethical Decision Making
nodes.description: A process that requires decision makers to consider and choose among alternatives that are consistent with ethical principles.

nodes.name: Confirmation Bias
nodes.description: The tendency to seek out information that reaffirms past choices and to discount information that contradicts them.

nodes.name: Escalation of Commitment
nodes.name_jp: コミットメントの段階的強化
nodes.description: An increased commitment to a previous decision in spite of negative information.

nodes.name: Groupthink
nodes.description: A phenomenon in which the norm for consensus overrides the realistic appraisal of alternative courses of action.

nodes.name: Common Biases in Decision Making
nodes.name_jp: 意思決定における一般的なバイアス
nodes.description: Systematic patterns of deviation from norm or rationality in judgment.

nodes.name: Brainstorming
nodes.name_jp: ブレインストーミング
nodes.description: An idea-generation process that specifically encourages any and all alternatives while withholding any criticism of those alternatives.

nodes.name: Nominal Group Technique
nodes.description: A group decision-making method where individual members meet face-to-face to pool their judgments in a systematic but independent fashion.

nodes.name: Delphi Technique
nodes.description: A group decision-making method where members never meet face-to-face. Input is solicited through a series of questionnaires.

nodes.name: Improving the Quality of Decision Making
nodes.description: Methods and techniques used to mitigate biases and enhance the effectiveness of individual and group decisions.

nodes.name: Chapter 7
nodes.description: Work Motivation for Performance

nodes.name: Work Motivation
nodes.name_jp: 組織における仕事の動機づけ
nodes.description: The psychological forces that determine the direction of a persons behavior in an organization, a person s level of effort, and a person s level of persistence.

nodes.name: Direction
nodes.description: The possible behaviors the individual could engage in.

nodes.name: Intensity
nodes.description: How hard the individual tries.

nodes.name: Content Theories
nodes.description: Theories that focus on what motivates people (needs and motives).

nodes.name: Process Theories
nodes.description: Theories that focus on how motivation occurs (the process of motivation).

nodes.name: Intrinsic Rewards
nodes.description: Rewards that come from the work itself, such as feeling of accomplishment or interest.

nodes.name: Extrinsic Rewards
nodes.description: Rewards that are external to the job, such as pay, benefits, or praise.

nodes.name: Learned Needs
nodes.description: Needs that are acquired over time through life experiences.

nodes.name: Need for Achievement (nAch)
nodes.description: The desire to excel, to achieve in relation to a set of standards, to strive to succeed.

nodes.name: Need for Affiliation (nAff)
nodes.description: The desire for friendly and close interpersonal relationships.

nodes.name: Need for Power (nPow)
nodes.description: The desire to influence or control others, to be responsible for others, and to have authority over others.

nodes.name: Manifest Need
nodes.description: A need that is active and influences behavior.

nodes.name: Hedonism
nodes.description: The pursuit of pleasure; sensual self-indulgence.

nodes.name: Instincts
nodes.description: Innate, fixed patterns of behavior in response to certain stimuli.

nodes.name: Personal Power Seeker
nodes.description: An individual who seeks power for personal gain and self-glorification.

nodes.name: Social Power Seeker
nodes.description: An individual who seeks power to help others and the organization.

nodes.name: Existence Needs
nodes.description: Desires for physiological and material well-being (Alderfer s ERG Theory).

nodes.name: Relatedness Needs
nodes.description: Desires for satisfying interpersonal relationships (Alderfer s ERG Theory).

nodes.name: Growth Needs
nodes.description: Desires for continued personal growth and development (Alderfer s ERG Theory).

nodes.name: Motivators
nodes.description: Factors that lead to job satisfaction, such as achievement, recognition, and responsibility (Herzberg s Theory).

nodes.name: Hygiene Factors
nodes.description: Factors that prevent job dissatisfaction, such as company policy, supervision, and salary (Herzberg s Theory).

nodes.name: Manifest Needs Theory
nodes.description: The theory that human behavior is driven by a set of needs that are active at any given time.

nodes.name: Learned Needs Theory (McClelland)
nodes.name_cn: 习得性需求理论（麦克利兰）
nodes.name_jp: 学習されたニーズ理論（マクレランド）
nodes.description: McClelland s theory that states achievement, power, and affiliation are three important needs that are acquired through life experiences.

nodes.name: Maslow s Hierarchy of Needs
nodes.name_jp: マズローの欲求階層説
nodes.description: A five-tier model of human needs, often depicted as hierarchical levels within a pyramid.

nodes.name: Alderfer s ERG Theory
nodes.name_jp: アルダーファーのERG理論
nodes.description: A simplification of Maslow s hierarchy into three categories: Existence, Relatedness, and Growth needs.

nodes.name: Herzberg s Motivator-Hygiene Theory
nodes.name_cn: 赫茨伯格的双因素理论
nodes.name_jp: ハーズバーグの動機づけ・衛生理論
nodes.description: The theory that job satisfaction and dissatisfaction are caused by different sets of factors (motivators and hygiene factors).

nodes.name: Self-Determination Theory
nodes.description: A macro theory of human motivation and personality that concerns people s inherent growth tendencies and innate psychological needs.

nodes.name: Operant Conditioning Theory
nodes.name_jp: オペラント条件づけ理論
nodes.description: A learning process through which the strength of a behavior is modified by reinforcement or punishment.

nodes.name: Equity Theory
nodes.description: The theory that individuals are motivated by a desire for fairness in their input-to-output ratio compared to others.

nodes.name: Goal Theory
nodes.description: The theory that specific and difficult goals, with feedback, lead to higher performance.

nodes.name: Expectancy Theory
nodes.description: The theory that motivation depends on the perceived link between effort, performance, and outcomes (rewards).

nodes.name: Chapter 8: Performance Appraisal and Rewards
nodes.description: This chapter explores the concept of motivation, various motivation theories, and how performance appraisal and reward systems are designed to influence employee behavior.

nodes.name: Performance Appraisal
nodes.description: A formal system of review and evaluation of individual or team task performance.

nodes.name: Rewards
nodes.description: Monetary and non-monetary benefits provided to employees in exchange for their work.

nodes.name: Content Theories of Motivation
nodes.description: Theories that focus on what internal factors energize behavior.

nodes.name: Process Theories of Motivation
nodes.description: Theories that focus on the process by which internal factors and cognitions influence behavior.

nodes.name: Organizational Justice
nodes.description: An employee’s perception of fairness in the workplace.

nodes.name: Goal Setting
nodes.description: The process of establishing desired results that guide and direct behavior.

nodes.name: ERG Theory
nodes.description: Alderfer’s theory that three groups of core needs—existence, relatedness, and growth—are the source of motivation.

nodes.name: Herzberg’s two-factor theory
nodes.name_cn: 赫茨伯格的双因素理论
nodes.name_jp: ハーズバーグの二要因理論
nodes.description: A theory that relates intrinsic factors to job satisfaction and extrinsic factors to job dissatisfaction.

nodes.name: Organizational Behavior Modification
nodes.description: Applying the principles of operant conditioning to organizational settings.

nodes.name: intensity
nodes.description: How hard a person tries.

nodes.name: direction
nodes.description: The orientation toward a beneficial goal.

nodes.name: intrinsic motivation
nodes.description: Motivation that comes from within a person, such as the enjoyment of the task itself.

nodes.name: extrinsic motivation
nodes.description: Motivation that comes from outside the person, such as pay, bonuses, or other tangible rewards.

nodes.name: effort-performance expectancy (E1)
nodes.description: The perceived probability that exerting a given amount of effort will lead to performance.

nodes.name: performance-outcome expectancy (E2)
nodes.description: The perceived probability that successfully performing at a particular level will lead to the attainment of a desired outcome.

nodes.name: valences
nodes.description: The attractiveness or importance of the potential outcome to the individual.

nodes.name: input
nodes.description: What an employee brings to the job (e.g., effort, experience, education).

nodes.name: outcome
nodes.description: What an employee gets from the job (e.g., pay, recognition, benefits).

nodes.name: referent others
nodes.description: The individuals or groups against which an employee compares their ratio of inputs to outcomes.

nodes.name: underreward inequity
nodes.description: The perception that one’s own outcome-to-input ratio is less than that of a referent other.

nodes.name: overreward inequity
nodes.description: The perception that one’s own outcome-to-input ratio is greater than that of a referent other.

nodes.name: goal commitment
nodes.description: The degree to which an individual is determined to reach a goal.

nodes.name: positive reinforcement
nodes.description: Following a response with something pleasant.

nodes.name: avoidance learning
nodes.description: Reinforcing a desired behavior by removing an unpleasant consequence (Negative Reinforcement).

nodes.name: punishment
nodes.description: Applying an undesirable consequence to decrease an undesirable behavior.

nodes.name: extinction
nodes.description: Withholding a positive consequence to decrease an undesirable behavior.

nodes.name: hygienes
nodes.description: Factors that prevent job dissatisfaction but do not lead to satisfaction (e.g., salary, working conditions, company policy).

nodes.name: need for achievement (nAch)
nodes.description: The drive to excel, to achieve in relation to a set of standards, and to strive to succeed.

nodes.name: need for power (nPow)
nodes.description: The need to make others behave in a way that they would not have behaved otherwise.

nodes.name: need for affiliation (nAff)
nodes.description: The desire for friendly and close interpersonal relationships.

nodes.name: Distributive Justice
nodes.description: Perceived fairness of the amount and allocation of rewards among individuals.

nodes.name: Procedural Justice
nodes.description: Perceived fairness of the process used to determine the distribution of rewards.

nodes.name: Chapter 9: Group and Intergroup Relations
nodes.name_cn: 第9章：群体与群体间关系
nodes.name_jp: 第9章：集団と集団間関係
nodes.description: The study of how groups form, their internal structure, dynamics, and how they interact with other groups.

nodes.name: Work Group Types and Formation
nodes.name_cn: 工作群体的类型与形成
nodes.name_jp: ワークグループの種類と形成
nodes.description: Different classifications of work groups and the process by which they are established.

nodes.name: Group Structure (Norms, Roles, Status)
nodes.name_cn: 群体结构（规范、角色、地位）
nodes.name_jp: 集団構造（規範、役割、地位）
nodes.description: The internal framework of a group, including established patterns of relationships, norms, roles, and status systems.

nodes.name: Group Cohesiveness and Effectiveness
nodes.name_jp: 集団の凝集性と有効性
nodes.description: The degree to which members are attracted to the group and motivated to stay in it, and how this relates to group performance.

nodes.name: Intergroup Behavior and Performance
nodes.name_jp: 集団間行動とパフォーマンス
nodes.description: The dynamics and outcomes of interactions between two or more groups.

nodes.name: Managing Interdependence and Conflict
nodes.name_cn: 相互依赖性与冲突的管理
nodes.name_jp: 相互依存性と対立の管理
nodes.description: Strategies for handling the reliance of groups on each other and resolving disagreements that arise.

nodes.name: Asch’s experiment in group pressure and individual judgment
nodes.name_cn: 阿希的群体压力与个体判断实验
nodes.name_jp: アッシュの集団圧力と個人判断に関する実験
nodes.description: A classic study demonstrating the power of conformity and group pressure on an individual's judgment.

nodes.name: Stages of Group Development (Forming, Storming, Norming, Performing)
nodes.name_cn: 群体发展阶段（形成、风暴、规范、执行）
nodes.name_jp: 集団発達の段階（形成期、混乱期、規範確立期、遂行期）
nodes.description: A model describing the five sequential stages that most groups go through: forming, storming, norming, performing, and adjourning (though adjourning is often omitted in OB context).

nodes.name: Role Episode Model
nodes.name_jp: 役割エピソードモデル
nodes.description: A model that explains how a person's role is defined and enacted through a series of interactions with others (role senders).

nodes.name: Work Groups: Basic Considerations
nodes.name_jp: ワークグループ：基本的考察
nodes.description: Fundamental definitions and distinctions of various types of work groups.

nodes.name: Work Group Structure
nodes.name_jp: ワークグループの構造
nodes.description: The elements that define the internal organization of a work group, such as norms, roles, and status.

nodes.name: Managing Effective Work Groups
nodes.name_jp: 効果的なワークグループの管理
nodes.description: Techniques and factors that contribute to a work group's high performance and goal achievement.

nodes.name: Intergroup Behavior and Performance
nodes.name_jp: 集団間行動とパフォーマンス
nodes.description: The study of how groups interact with each other and the resulting impact on organizational performance.

nodes.name: Command group
nodes.description: A group composed of the employees who report directly to a given manager.

nodes.name: Decoupling
nodes.description: A strategy to reduce the need for coordination between interdependent groups.

nodes.name: Formal group
nodes.description: A work group defined by the organization's structure with designated work assignments and established tasks.

nodes.name: Friendship group
nodes.description: An informal group that forms because the individual members have one or more common characteristics.

nodes.name: Group
nodes.description: Two or more individuals, interacting and interdependent, who have come together to achieve particular objectives.

nodes.name: Group cohesiveness
nodes.description: The degree to which group members are attracted to each other and are motivated to stay in the group.

nodes.name: Informal group
nodes.description: A group that is neither formally structured nor organizationally determined; appears in response to the need for social contact.

nodes.name: Information flow
nodes.description: The pattern of communication among group members or between groups.

nodes.name: Interaction process analysis
nodes.description: A technique for observing and classifying the verbal behaviors of group members.

nodes.name: Interest group
nodes.description: An informal group that forms to attain a specific objective with which each member is concerned.

nodes.name: Linking role
nodes.description: A role whose primary purpose is to coordinate the activities of two or more groups.

nodes.name: Norms
nodes.description: Acceptable standards of behavior within a group that are shared by the group's members.

nodes.name: Pooled interdependence
nodes.description: The lowest level of interdependence, where groups work independently and their output is simply aggregated.

nodes.name: Reciprocal interdependence
nodes.description: The highest level of interdependence, where the output of one group becomes the input for another, and vice versa.

nodes.name: Role ambiguity
nodes.description: A person's uncertainty about what is expected of him or her in a particular role.

nodes.name: Role conflict
nodes.description: A situation in which an individual is confronted by divergent role expectations.

nodes.name: Role episode
nodes.description: A sequence of events involving role senders, the focal person, and the resulting role behavior.

nodes.name: Role overload
nodes.description: A condition in which an individual is expected to do more than time or ability permits.

nodes.name: Role set
nodes.description: All the different role senders who influence a focal person's role.

nodes.name: Sequential interdependence
nodes.description: A moderate level of interdependence, where the output of one group becomes the input for the next group.

nodes.name: Social loafing
nodes.description: The tendency for individuals to expend less effort when working collectively than when working individually.

nodes.name: Status incongruence
nodes.description: A situation where a person's various statuses are not aligned or consistent with each other.

nodes.name: Status system
nodes.description: A formal or informal system that differentiates group members based on prestige, power, or rank.

nodes.name: Task force
nodes.description: A temporary formal group created to accomplish a specific, short-term task.

nodes.name: Task group
nodes.description: A formal group composed of employees who work together to complete a job task.

nodes.name: Task uncertainty
nodes.description: The degree to which the exact nature of the task and the methods for accomplishing it are unclear.

nodes.name: Work role
nodes.description: A set of expected behavior patterns attributed to someone occupying a given position in a social unit.

nodes.name: Work technology
nodes.description: The process by which an organization transforms inputs into outputs.

nodes.name: Leadership
nodes.description: The study of how individuals influence others to achieve a common goal.

nodes.name: Leader Traits
nodes.description: Innate or acquired characteristics that distinguish leaders from non-leaders.

nodes.name: Leadership as an Exercise of Influence
nodes.name_cn: 作为影响力行使的领导力
nodes.name_jp: 影響力としてのリーダーシップ
nodes.description: The process of influencing a group toward the achievement of goals.

nodes.name: Leader Behaviors
nodes.description: Observable actions and activities of leaders.

nodes.name: Situational Leadership
nodes.name_jp: 状況的リーダーシップ
nodes.description: Leadership effectiveness depends on the situation and the readiness of followers.

nodes.name: Cross-Cultural Context of Leadership
nodes.name_jp: 異文化間リーダーシップ
nodes.description: How cultural values influence leadership styles and effectiveness.

nodes.name: Great Man Theory
nodes.description: The belief that leaders are born, not made, possessing heroic qualities.

nodes.name: Trait Approach to Leadership
nodes.description: Focuses on identifying the personal characteristics that differentiate leaders from followers.

nodes.name: Leadership Grid (Blake and Mouton)
nodes.name_jp: リーダーシップ・グリッド
nodes.description: A model that identifies five different leadership styles based on a leader's concern for people and concern for production.

nodes.name: Path-Goal Theory of Leadership
nodes.description: A contingency theory that states a leader's behavior is acceptable to subordinates to the degree that they view it as a source of immediate or future satisfaction.

nodes.name: Idiosyncrasy Credits
nodes.description: The positive impressions a leader accumulates, allowing them to deviate from group norms without penalty.

nodes.name: Leadership Motivation
nodes.description: The desire to influence and lead others.

nodes.name: Self-Confidence
nodes.description: Belief in one's own ability to succeed.

nodes.name: Cognitive Ability
nodes.description: The capacity to learn, reason, and solve problems.

nodes.name: Concern for Results
nodes.description: The degree to which a leader emphasizes organizational efficiency and task accomplishment.

nodes.name: Concern for People
nodes.description: The degree to which a leader emphasizes employee needs, relationships, and well-being.

nodes.name: Directive Leadership
nodes.name_jp: 指示的リーダーシップ
nodes.description: The leader lets subordinates know what is expected of them, gives specific guidance, and schedules work.

nodes.name: Supportive Leadership
nodes.name_jp: 支援的リーダーシップ
nodes.description: The leader is friendly and shows concern for the status, well-being, and needs of subordinates.

nodes.name: Participative Leadership
nodes.name_jp: 参加的リーダーシップ
nodes.description: The leader consults with subordinates and uses their suggestions before making a decision.

nodes.name: Achievement-Oriented Leadership
nodes.name_jp: 達成志向的リーダーシップ
nodes.description: The leader sets challenging goals and expects subordinates to perform at their highest level.

nodes.name: Communication
nodes.description: The transfer and understanding of meaning.

nodes.name: Communication Process
nodes.name_jp: コミュニケーションプロセス
nodes.description: The steps between a source and a receiver that result in the transfer and understanding of meaning.

nodes.name: Types of Organizational Communication
nodes.name_jp: 組織コミュニケーションのタイプ
nodes.description: Different forms and directions of communication within an organization.

nodes.name: Influences on Communication
nodes.name_jp: コミュニケーションへの影響
nodes.description: Factors like power, status, and interpersonal skills that affect communication effectiveness.

nodes.name: Corporate Reputation and Communication
nodes.name_jp: 企業評判とコミュニケーション
nodes.description: How communication strategies impact and are impacted by an organization's reputation.

nodes.name: Managerial Communication Skills
nodes.name_jp: 管理者のコミュニケーションスキル
nodes.description: Skills such as talking, listening, reading, and writing essential for effective management.

nodes.name: Media Richness Theory
nodes.name_jp: メディアリッチネス理論
nodes.description: A framework for selecting the appropriate communication channel based on its capacity to convey information.

nodes.name: Sender
nodes.description: The source of the message.

nodes.name: Encoding
nodes.description: Converting a message to symbolic form.

nodes.name: Channel
nodes.description: The medium through which the message travels.

nodes.name: Decoding
nodes.description: Translating a sender’s message.

nodes.name: Receiver
nodes.description: The person to whom the message is directed.

nodes.name: Noise
nodes.description: Communication barriers that distort the clarity of the message.

nodes.name: Feedback
nodes.description: The check on how successful the message was transferred.

nodes.name: Formal Communication
nodes.name_jp: 公式コミュニケーション
nodes.description: Communication that follows the official chain of command.

nodes.name: Informal Communication
nodes.name_jp: 非公式コミュニケーション
nodes.description: Communication that is not officially sanctioned by the organization.

nodes.name: Downward Communication
nodes.name_jp: 下方コミュニケーション
nodes.description: Communication that flows from a higher level to a lower level in the organization.

nodes.name: Upward Communication
nodes.name_jp: 上方コミュニケーション
nodes.description: Communication that flows to a higher level in the organization.

nodes.name: Horizontal Communication
nodes.name_jp: 水平コミュニケーション
nodes.description: Communication among members at the same level.

nodes.name: Grapevine
nodes.name_jp: 非公式ネットワーク (うわさ)
nodes.description: The organization’s informal communication network.

nodes.name: Media Richness
nodes.description: The capacity of a communication channel to convey information.

nodes.name: Active Listening
nodes.name_jp: アクティブリスニング
nodes.description: Fully concentrating on what is being said rather than just passively hearing the message.

nodes.name: Effective Writing
nodes.name_jp: 効果的なライティング
nodes.description: The ability to convey a message clearly and concisely in written form.

nodes.name: Power
nodes.description: The ability to influence communication flow and content.

nodes.name: Status
nodes.description: An individual's position in the hierarchy affecting communication patterns.

nodes.name: Interpersonal Skills
nodes.description: The ability to interact effectively with others, crucial for communication.

nodes.name: Power Dependencies
nodes.description: Concept related to Power Dependencies in organizational behavior.

nodes.name: Authority
nodes.description: Concept related to Authority in organizational behavior.

nodes.name: Ethical Use of Power
nodes.name_jp: パワーの倫理的な使用
nodes.description: Concept related to Ethical Use of Power in organizational behavior.

nodes.name: Etzioni's Types of Power (Coercive, Utilitarian, Normative)
nodes.name_cn: 埃齐奥尼的权力类型（强制性、功利性、规范性）
nodes.name_jp: エツィオーニのパワーの類型（強制的、功利的、規範的）
nodes.description: Etzioni's model describing how different types of power evoke different levels of involvement.

nodes.name: Legitimate Power
nodes.description: Power based on a person’s position in the formal hierarchy.

nodes.name: Organizational Politics Direct Feedback
nodes.name_jp: 組織政治の直接的なフィードバック

nodes.name: Reward Power
nodes.description: Compliance achieved based on the ability to distribute rewards.

nodes.name: Political Skill in Interpersonal Relations
nodes.name_cn: 人际关系中的政治技能
nodes.name_jp: 対人関係における政治的スキル

nodes.name: Building Coalitions or Politicking
nodes.name_cn: 建立联盟或进行政治活动
nodes.name_jp: 連盟の構築または政治活動

nodes.name: French and Raven's Bases of Power
nodes.name_cn: 弗伦奇和雷文的权力基础
nodes.name_jp: フレンチとレイヴンのパワーの源泉

nodes.name: Conflict and Negotiations
nodes.description: Examining the nature, types, resolution strategies, and negotiation processes of conflict in organizations.

nodes.name: Conflict
nodes.description: A process that begins when one party perceives that another party has negatively affected, or is about to negatively affect, something that the first party cares about.

nodes.name: Conflict as a Process
nodes.name_jp: コンフリクトのプロセス
nodes.description: The five stages of conflict: potential opposition, cognition and personalization, intentions, behavior, and outcomes.

nodes.name: Negotiation
nodes.description: A process in which two or more parties exchange goods or services and attempt to agree upon the exchange rate for them.

nodes.name: Negotiation Process
nodes.description: The steps involved in negotiation: preparation, ground rules, clarification, bargaining, and closure.

nodes.name: Procedural Conflict
nodes.name_jp: 手続き上のコンフリクト

nodes.name: BATNA
nodes.description: Best Alternative to a Negotiated Agreement; the lowest acceptable value to an individual for a negotiated agreement.

nodes.name: Chapter 15: External and Internal Organizational Environments and Corporate Culture
nodes.name_cn: 第15章：外部和内部组织环境与企业文化
nodes.name_jp: 第15章：外部・内部組織環境と企業文化
nodes.description: 組織行動学における外部環境、内部環境、組織構造、組織文化の概念を探る。

nodes.name: External and Internal Organizational Environments
nodes.description: 組織を取り巻く外部要因と、組織内の構造・文化などの内部要因。

nodes.name: Environmental Uncertainty
nodes.description: 組織の外部環境における変化の度合いと複雑さ。

nodes.name: Organizational Complexity
nodes.description: 組織内の分化、階層、地理的分散の度合い。

nodes.name: Mechanistic vs. Organic Structures
nodes.name_jp: 機械的組織構造 対 有機的組織構造
nodes.description: 組織構造の設計に関する二つの対照的なモデル。

nodes.name: Types of Organizational Structures
nodes.description: 機能別、事業部別、マトリックス、ネットワーク型などの具体的な組織構造。

nodes.name: Open Systems Theory
nodes.name_jp: オープンシステム理論
nodes.description: 組織を環境と相互作用するシステムとして捉える理論。

nodes.name: Internal Organizational Dimensions
nodes.description: 組織の内部構造を定義する要素（専門化、標準化、集権化など）。

nodes.name: McKinsey 7-S Model
nodes.name_jp: マッキンゼーの7Sモデル
nodes.description: 組織の有効性を分析するための7つの相互に関連する要素（戦略、構造、システム、共有価値、スキル、スタッフ、スタイル）。

nodes.name: Corporate Culture
nodes.description: 組織のメンバーが共有する価値観、信念、規範。

nodes.name: Environment-Industry-Organization "Fit" Framework
nodes.name_cn: 环境-产业-组织“契合”框架
nodes.name_jp: 環境-産業-組織「適合」フレームワーク
nodes.description: 組織の構造が環境と産業の特性に適合している必要があるという考え方。

nodes.name: Mechanistic vs. Organic Organizational Structures Model
nodes.name_cn: 机械式与有机式组织结构模型
nodes.name_jp: 機械的組織構造 対 有機的組織構造モデル
nodes.description: BurnsとStalkerによる、環境に応じて適切な組織構造を提唱したモデル。

nodes.name: Lewin and Stephens Unifying Framework
nodes.name_cn: 勒温和斯蒂芬斯统一框架
nodes.name_jp: レヴィンとスティーブンスの統合フレームワーク
nodes.description: 組織行動学の様々な側面を統合的に理解するためのフレームワーク。

nodes.name: Environmental Complexity
nodes.description: 組織が対処しなければならない外部要素の数と多様性。

nodes.name: Environmental Change
nodes.description: 外部環境の要素が時間とともに変化する頻度と予測可能性。

nodes.name: Mechanistic Organizational Structures
nodes.description: 厳格な階層、集権化、高度な標準化を特徴とする構造。

nodes.name: Organic Organizational Structures
nodes.description: 柔軟な構造、分権化、低い標準化を特徴とする構造。

nodes.name: Functional Structure
nodes.description: 専門分野（マーケティング、製造など）に基づいて部門を編成する構造。

nodes.name: Divisional Structure
nodes.description: 製品、サービス、顧客、または地理に基づいて部門を編成する構造。

nodes.name: Matrix Structure
nodes.name_jp: マトリックス組織構造
nodes.description: 機能別と事業部別の構造を組み合わせ、二重の報告関係を持つ構造。

nodes.name: Networked Team Structures
nodes.name_jp: ネットワーク型チーム構造
nodes.description: 柔軟で自律的なチーム間の連携に依存する構造。

nodes.name: Virtual Structures
nodes.description: 主要な機能の多くを外部の企業に委託し、中央のハブが調整する構造。

nodes.name: Open Systems
nodes.description: 環境からインプットを受け取り、スループットを経て、アウトプットを環境に返すシステム。

nodes.name: Through-put
nodes.description: オープンシステムにおいて、インプットをアウトプットに変換するプロセス。

nodes.name: Organizational Structure and Change
nodes.description: Discusses the design of organizational structures and the process of managing organizational change.

nodes.name: Organizational Structure
nodes.description: The formal arrangement of jobs within an organization.

nodes.name: Organizational Change
nodes.description: Any alteration of an organization's people, structure, or technology.

nodes.name: Formal Organization
nodes.description: The official, structured relationships and roles defined by management.

nodes.name: Informal Organization
nodes.description: The unofficial, unwritten, and often unspoken relationships and norms that exist within an organization.

nodes.name: Mechanistic Organizational Structures
nodes.description: A structure characterized by high specialization, rigid departmentalization, clear chain of command, narrow spans of control, and centralization.

nodes.name: Organic Organizational Structures
nodes.description: A structure that is highly adaptive and flexible, with little formalization, decentralized decision-making, and wide spans of control.

nodes.name: Functional Structure
nodes.description: An organizational design that groups similar or related occupational specialties together.

nodes.name: Divisional Structure
nodes.description: An organizational structure made up of separate business units or divisions.

nodes.name: Geographic Structure
nodes.description: A divisional structure organized around specific geographic regions.

nodes.name: Matrix Structure
nodes.description: A structure that assigns specialists from different functional departments to work on one or more projects.

nodes.name: Networked-Team Structure
nodes.name_jp: ネットワーク型チーム組織
nodes.description: A structure where employees continuously work on projects in teams that are formed, dissolved, and reformed as needed.

nodes.name: Virtual Structure
nodes.description: An organization that consists of a small core of full-time employees and temporarily hires outside specialists to work on opportunities that arise.

nodes.name: Planned Change
nodes.description: Change activities that are intentional and goal-oriented.

nodes.name: Unplanned Change
nodes.description: Change that is unexpected and often reactive, resulting from external forces or crises.

nodes.name: Incremental Change
nodes.description: Small, continuous changes that fine-tune the organization.

nodes.name: Transformational Change
nodes.description: Radical, organization-wide changes that result in a major overhaul of the organization's mission, structure, and culture.

nodes.name: Change Agent
nodes.description: A person who acts as a catalyst and assumes the responsibility for managing change activities.

nodes.name: Resistance to Change
nodes.description: Actions or behaviors that attempt to slow down or stop the change process.

nodes.name: Lewin's Three-Step Model
nodes.name_jp: レヴィンの三段階モデル
nodes.description: A model for change consisting of unfreezing, movement (change), and refreezing.

nodes.name: Kotter's Eight-Step Model
nodes.name_jp: コッターの8段階モデル
nodes.description: A detailed sequence of steps for leading organizational change, starting with establishing a sense of urgency.

nodes.name: Appreciative Inquiry (AI)
nodes.name_jp: アプリシエイティブ・インクワイアリー
nodes.description: An approach that seeks to identify the unique strengths and best practices of an organization and build upon them.

nodes.name: Human Resource Management
nodes.description: The strategic and comprehensive approach to managing people and the workplace culture.

nodes.name: Employee Life Cycle
nodes.description: The various stages an employee goes through from recruitment to exit.

nodes.name: Entrepreneurship
nodes.description: 新しい事業を立ち上げ、それに伴うリスクを引き受け、利益を得るプロセス。

nodes.name: Corporate Entrepreneurship
nodes.description: 既存の大企業内で新しい事業やイノベーションを開発する活動。

nodes.name: Social Entrepreneurship
nodes.description: 社会的・環境的な問題解決を主な目的とする事業活動。

nodes.name: Business Model Canvas (BMC)
nodes.name_jp: ビジネスモデルキャンバス
nodes.description: 事業の主要な構成要素を視覚的に表現するための戦略的マネジメントツール。

nodes.name: Global Entrepreneurship Monitor (GEM) model
nodes.name_jp: グローバル起業家モニター（GEM）モデル
nodes.description: 国際的な起業活動のレベルと決定要因を測定するフレームワーク。

nodes.name: Value Proposition
nodes.description: 顧客が抱える問題を解決し、ニーズを満たすために企業が提供する製品やサービスの価値。

nodes.name: Customer Segments
nodes.description: 企業がリーチし、サービスを提供したいと考える異なる人々のグループ。

nodes.name: Channels
nodes.description: 企業が顧客セグメントとコミュニケーションを取り、価値提案を届ける方法。

nodes.name: Revenue Streams
nodes.description: 企業が顧客セグメントに価値提案を成功裏に提供することで得られる収入。

nodes.name: Key Resources
nodes.description: 価値提案の提供、チャネルの確立、顧客セグメントとの関係維持、収益の創出に必要な最も重要な資産。

nodes.name: Key Activities
nodes.description: 価値提案の提供、チャネルの確立、顧客セグメントとの関係維持、収益の創出に必要な最も重要な行動。

nodes.name: Types of Entrepreneurs
nodes.description: 異なる動機や事業形態を持つ起業家の分類。

nodes.name: Characteristics of Successful Entrepreneurs
nodes.name_jp: 成功する起業家の特性
nodes.description: 成功した起業家が共通して持つとされるパーソナリティ特性やスキル。
